page.title: 01THE HAILES ABBEY AREA
page.content: The area is sparsely populated and mainly agricultural.It has no towns or villages and the inhabitants live in individual farmhouses and hamlets.The area has been inhabited since prehistoric times,and there are many signs of this remaining today.They include an earthwork at Beckbury Camp,an Anglo_Saxon church at Farmcote, a medieval abbey at Hailes and farmhouses going back to Tudor times.The landscape has much variety and forms part of the Cotswold escarpment,which runs from North East to South West across the area.This variety explains the range of agriculture to be found in the area: fruit cultivation,arable and sheep farming.There has been little economic development and the landscape remains very much as it must have been when the first Domesday Book was compiled.
